section.title: MySQL with Galera
section.para: Rather than starting with a vanilla version of MySQL, and then adding Galera, you will want to install a version of MySQL patched for wsrep (Write Set REPlication) from https://launchpad.net/codership-mysql/0.7. The wsrep API is suitable for configuring MySQL High Availability in OpenStack because it supports synchronous replication.
Note that the installation requirements call for careful attention. Read the guide https://launchpadlibrarian.net/66669857/README-wsrep to ensure you follow all the required steps.

orderedlist.title: Installing Galera through a MySQL version patched for wsrep:

listitem.para: Download Galera from https://launchpad.net/galera/+download, and install the *.rpms or *.debs, which takes care of any dependencies that your system doesn’t already have installed.
In the system-wide my.conf file, make sure mysqld isn’t bound to 127.0.0.1, and that /etc/mysql/conf.d/ is included. Typically you can find this file at /etc/my.cnf:
When adding a new node, you must configure it with a MySQL account that can access the other nodes. The new node must be able to request a state snapshot from one of the existing nodes:
Specify your MySQL account information in /etc/mysql/conf.d/wsrep.cnf:
Connect as root and grant privileges to that user:

screen.userinput: mysql -e "SET wsrep_on=OFF; GRANT ALL ON *.* TO wsrep_sst@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'wspass'";

listitem.para: Remove user accounts with empty user names because they cause problems:

screen.userinput: mysql -e "SET wsrep_on=OFF; DELETE FROM mysql.user WHERE user='';"

listitem.para: Set up certain mandatory configuration options within MySQL itself. These include:
Check that the nodes can access each other through the firewall. Depending on your environment, this might mean adjusting iptables, as in:

screen.userinput: iptables --insert RH-Firewall-1-INPUT 1 --proto tcp \ --source <my IP>/24 --destination <my IP>/32 --dport 3306 \ -j ACCEPT
iptables --insert RH-Firewall-1-INPUT 1 --proto tcp \ --source <my IP>/24 --destination <my IP>/32 --dport 4567 \ -j ACCEPT

listitem.para: This might also mean configuring any NAT firewall between nodes to allow direct connections. You might need to disable SELinux, or configure it to allow mysqld to listen to sockets at unprivileged ports.

section.para: Now you’re ready to create the cluster.
